subsection.title: Evaluating Pieces of Different Functions
subsection.p: A piecewise defined function is literally a function that has been defined in pieces. Most likely you have encountered piecewise defined functions in every day life. Maybe you didn't know what they were called.

For instance, the cost to park downtown will have a flat fee for the first hour, then some different hourly rate for up to some max, all day fee. To calculate the cost of parking there are various formulas, each one is a piece of the whole cost function.

The most difficult part of piecewise functions is the notation. In the following set of activities you will use a skill you already know, evaluate a function graphically, and transition slowly into how to write and understand piecewise notation.

subsection.title: One Function Pieced Together
subsection.p: In the previous exercise you identified the equations of three separate lines and you stated the intervals for which each line was to be used. In fact, you stated the domain for each equation. When two or more equations are put together to form one function it's called a piecewise defined function. The function has to state what all the formulas are and it also has to let the reader know when to use them. In short, the notation has to let the reader know the equations and their domains.
Next we learn how to set up the notation so that a reader can easily identify each formula and it's corresponding domain.

subsection.title: Graphing a Piecewise Defined Function
subsection.p: We can now use our understanding of piecewise noation to read piecewise functions and graph them. Remember, the domain of a function is the collection of inputs for which the function exists. On a graph, a function is visible only for inputs in its domain and it is not visible for inputs outside its domain.
